questions.question: Indemnity in insurance most closely means:
options: Paying whatever the policyholder believes is fair
Providing financial compensation to place the policyholder in the same position as immediately before the loss
Replacing the item regardless of depreciation
Paying the new replacement cost in all cases
questions.correctAnswer: Providing financial compensation to place the policyholder in the same position as immediately before the loss
questions.explanation: Core definition: restore, not improve, the policyholder’s financial position (subject to policy terms/limits).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a policy of indemnity?
questions.explanation: Personal accident/sickness/critical illness are benefit policies (no strict indemnity).

questions.question: Typical ways an insurer can provide indemnity include:
questions.explanation: Policies may allow any of these options to deliver indemnity.

questions.question: Reinstatement is most likely to apply to:
options: Only items less than one year old
questions.explanation: Reinstatement is a building (and sometimes machinery) concept; repair does not involve taking 'occupation' of premises.

questions.question: ‘New for old’ cover typically:
options: Is strict indemnity with wear & tear deducted
Pays replacement without wear & tear deduction
questions.correctAnswer: Pays replacement without wear & tear deduction
questions.explanation: New-for-old replaces at current cost (subject to conditions) rather than applying depreciation.

questions.question: A first-loss policy:
options: Insures for total value and offers a large premium discount
Insures for less than full value where total loss is improbable
Is the same as agreed value
questions.correctAnswer: Insures for less than full value where total loss is improbable
questions.explanation: Premium saving is modest as the insurer still pays all individual claims up to the first-loss limit.

questions.question: An agreed value clause most closely means:
options: The insurer will agree any claim value proposed by the policyholder
A fixed sum is pre-agreed for the insured item for claim purposes
Payment is always actual cash value
questions.correctAnswer: A fixed sum is pre-agreed for the insured item for claim purposes
questions.explanation: Agreed value sets the settlement figure in advance, avoiding later valuation disputes.

questions.question: If sum insured is 75% of true value and the loss is $40,000, with average applying, settlement is:
questions.explanation: Average reduces the claim in the same proportion as underinsurance (0.75 × $40,000 = $30,000).

questions.question: A deductible (excess) of $500 generally means:
options: The insurer reduces each payable claim by $500
The policyholder always pays 50% of the claim
questions.correctAnswer: The insurer reduces each payable claim by $500
questions.explanation: Excess/deductible is the first part of each loss borne by the insured.

questions.question: A valuable ring worth $6,000 is stolen under contents cover with a single-article limit of $2,500. Assuming no specified item extension:
options: $2,500 is the maximum payable (before any excess)
questions.correctAnswer: $2,500 is the maximum payable (before any excess)
questions.explanation: Item/single-article limits cap the insurer’s liability for certain items.

questions.question: A liability policy provides indemnity for:
options: Legal liability to pay damages and claimant’s costs (up to the limit)
questions.correctAnswer: Legal liability to pay damages and claimant’s costs (up to the limit)
questions.explanation: Liability policies indemnify legal liability rather than property value.

questions.question: Paying claims at current replacement cost without deducting wear and tear is known as ________ cover.
questions.explanation: Both terms are commonly encountered; many home contents are on a new-for-old basis.

flashcards.definition: Restore the insured to the same financial position as immediately before the loss (no better, no worse).
Personal accident/sickness/critical illness etc. are not contracts of indemnity.
Pre-agreed settlement amount for specified property.
Insures for less than full value where total loss is unlikely; modest premium saving.
Claim reduced in proportion to underinsurance.
Caps on insurer liability for certain articles (e.g., jewellery) unless specified separately.
First part of each loss borne by the insured.
Pays current market value with wear & tear deducted (contrast with new-for-old/reinstatement).
